text: It is interesting to be at this point and not know all six I’m voting for in the Council elections. I’ve had candidates offer to meet/call and then blow it off. I still don’t know what many stand for. It’s really odd. I like to think I follow this all closely, but I’m genuinely unsure.

I know Agenda Alexandria is a cesspool of insanity. Once I’m done with grad school I will spend some time thinking about how we create a true progressive issues forum for our city. #ProgressAlexandria
Agenda Alexandria continues its role as an anti-everything group disguised as a public policy debating club. patch.com/virginia/del...
I really hate seeing Dem primary candidates encouraging republicans to vote for them in the Dem primary’s

Yes, we have invested a lot in infrastructure in recent years (sewers anybody?) and while a lot of that has been deferred for a long time and was needed, it is harder to pay for when commercial tax base is falling.

It is hard not to see a need to raise taxes for a while to deal with staff salary pressures. But that’s obviously unsustainable given residential tax burden. Landmark Mall Redev will help, but it isn’t a solution.

Mayoral race positions update:
1) Jackson - oppose economic development and raise taxes.
2) Petersen - oppose economic development and cut taxes. 
3) Gaskins - Be thoughtful and strategic about taxes and economic development.
Property taxes watch out….
One week it’s a push for higher taxes. Another it’s a push to stop economic development. That is quite a vision.
Tonight I’m combining a vanilla simple with a rosemary simple.
I’m on my second old fashioned. I have to say, the homemade infused syrups and cherries make a big difference.
I’ll make you a cocktail
Friday pizza and movie night may be the most underrated event in American life.

It is all over, not just entry level. As one example, I know the City is having a very hard time hiring mental health staff and keeps losing people to other places they pay more and have less paperwork. The City issues are significantly greater than the schools.
Exactly. The City is well behind market expectations. Big issue. Actually much bigger issue for City than schools.

The dramatic levels of staff vacancies throughout local government are shocking. Public safety, sheriff, human services, everything. This has ramifications for public safety, for mental health crisis, for students, families and more. We need a comprehensive strategy to deal with this.
Lots of work. It takes lots of work.

As somebody with a serious mental health condition, I don’t think it has to always be this desperate. It can be hard sometimes, sure…but there can also be long periods of normalcy and, dare I say it, joy.
And all the other staff that also help the city like fire, police, mental health workers, etc.

As somebody that once owned a house on that storm water system, I know the storm water system lacks capacity. I don’t know if using the sewer would work, but at least it would take pressure off the storm water system.

In fairness, it is a really odd place for a house, literally surrounded by other houses. But this application and its most prominent opponents  are also ripe with a lot of irony. They should just vacate the alley.
Yes, but 4 doesn’t solve the school funding issue or the  ITT staff pay/vacancy issues. That add-delete process will be a real dogfight.

As I consider how bad the teacher pay, public safety pay, mental health pay and related issues are around Virginia and the US, it is hard to look at the proposed State budget and think anything but they are kicking the can to local governments to deal with.
Whatever the rate, excited to hear the anti arena/entertainment people yelling about big tax increases.
I agree those non pay factors are huge. Ignoring them is a real leadership issue.
Perhaps. This is on the conservative side for all the need. Pay issues and vacancy rates actually a lot worse on the city side than the schools.
This is ambitious, but possible. It would be a split vote, I think.

Yeah, I think 4 is very likely. It isn’t enough to come close to fixing the issues, but it provides some room to do some band-aid stuff. The problem isn’t just schools. Vacancy rates and staffing issues are actually much higher outside the schools where we are not competitive with pay.
Bluesky Alexandria - bets on how high they at the Tax rate ceiling tonight?

Learned today that Alexandria’s dept of Human Services has about an 18% vacancy rate (a lot due to uncompetitive pay). This department is critical to help the families of kids that struggle in our schools. Teachers can’t do it all. Without this help, they will fail.
Have you ever gotten addicted to a certain kind of sadness?
Pleasure to help

I mean sure, stick to your strict conformist stuff. They say I gotta learn, but nobody's here to teach me
If they can't understand it, how can they reach me? I guess they can't, I guess they won't. I guess they front, that's why I know.
Becky, I ran with the rain theme. Keep up.

When the sun shines, we'll shine together
Told you I'll be here forever
Said I'll always be your friend
Took an oath, I'ma stick it out to the end
Now that it's raining more than ever
Know that we'll still have each other
You can stand under my umbrella
My 16 week spring to graduate early starts tomorrow. See you on the other side!
Looks like Mr. Peterson has decided to try and buy an Alexandria mayoral job. This certainly shakes up the political dynamic for mayor. My best guess is it helps Aliya.
Was nice to hear POTUS talk about need for more housing supply to address housing & rent costs.

Hard not to be shocked that the VA Senate is leaving economic dev deals on the table because they have not added Senators to the MEI. Also amazed at how NOVA is getting treated so poorly by the Senate. And no press is writing about all this.

I think the politics in Alexandria have a long history of being hyper careful about taxes at expense of results. I am as guilty of this as anyone. I’d actually argue last two councils have been more aggressive about infrastructure needs than any group in a long time.

I agree these are tough calls. I do think there is a very human desire to support people that have invested in and taken risks on your community. It isn’t as black and white as just build something different. Politics does involve relationships, trustworthiness, etc.
I don’t want to wade it too much here, but he was looking for other sites when I was on council a while ago. It’s a real challenge to find suitable sites.
He has other options than just DC. He isn’t a successful person by accident. He understands negotiations and having back up plans. Assuming he doesn’t is foolish.
This is an important conversation! www.alxnow.com/2024/03/07/a...

Arena is dead without a special session. That could happen. Deals often get made when pressure is highest. But if I’m Leonsis, I’m pretty tired of Virginia right now. I don’t see why he doesn’t just pull out. A lot of Alexandria folks have made it clear they prefer higher taxes.

Each step requires deeper analysis and review. Only question right now is do we know enough to do more research and review. I think that is a yes, but I still reserve the right to be against this if the land use details don’t make sense to me.

I think it is helpful to remember that this is a long process with a lot of approval points. There is the initial deal framework. Then the legal authority to create the deal (where we are now). And then a lot of land use reviews (which will be the most detailed and lengthy process).

And Crystal City and Fairfax are also building which adds to Rt 1. Lots of variables. Easy to just throw hands up. But I do know this project is about only way City would get funds for traffic improvements in the PYard area. There is never perfect information in any land use decision.

I think we often overlook the co-owned music venue and office building that come with the Arena. The Arena definitely adds the fire power to support/boost the number of restaurants and related “fun” things, but we have wanted entertainment uses in that area.

It is a really hard thing to do and if not done well is legally a taking of one’s property rights. City has don’t it a few times and it was not simple. And then there is the popularity of Target in the community…
I think it would be nearly impossible to force/push the land owner to Redev the strip mall without big economic upside.

The retail wouldn’t be that significant, but I agree that part of our overall econ dev strategy needs to include looking at whether there are any housing types that create significant revenue benefits to the city. Young people and retired people both come to mind. And both groups need housing’s

Alexandria (and surrounding areas) subsidize almost all commercial economic development. There are a lot of rich businesses and people getting subsidy. Ithink the City has done a good job of mitigating risk (including getting sign off from the folks that give the city a AAA bond rating).
Looking at Arlington county board candidates.

Honest question for anti Alexandria arena folks. Do you support more property tax increases or service cuts to deal with city’s tax base imbalance issues? Or so you have a different economic dev strategy? It is easy to be against things. What are you for?

Hard not to laugh a bit at local gov candidates that say they will solve the affordability issues without any zoning changes. It’s quite a tall tale they are selling. I imagine they also know how to bring unicorns back to life?
With Haley out and Biden and Trump essentially set, the collective anxiety of the US is now peaking and the Zillow searches for homes abroad is skyrocketing.
And yet so many in Alexandria fight efforts to make things more walkable.

I have Sat though enough of these presentations to hear good answers to all of these. My view is this has really been thought through. But I’d direct you to Cory web site or a member of Council. They are all pretty well informed.

We are very diverse. Perhaps that is a form of excellence. Where am I going with this? Well, I think we do a mediocre or just good enough job at a lot of things. We don’t go big or bold or visionary for much. And isn’t that a missed opportunity?
Our mental health services are not as good as surrounding areas, especially Arlington. Our transit system is pretty good, but is it excellent? I don’t know. Perhaps.

Thought exercise. Alexandria is a very wealthy and well educated city. What are we excellent at? Other than being charming and having tourism, I am struggling to come up with an answer. Our schools struggle to educate all kids. Our parks are nowhere as nice as Arlington. Our mental health services…

There is so much fear mongering about the financing. That said, I think opposition is less about financing or taxes and a lot more about a belief that quaint little Alexandria just isn’t compatible with an urban Arena…no matter how it is financed.

I wonder how the dynamic would change if the Arena proposal included real taxpayer handouts from the general fund of the city and state and then was renegotiated to its current state where it is only being paid for with revenues generated by the project? I doubt it would make a big difference…but
Also, any council candidate articulating a real vision for how we make our schools excellent would likely get my 6th vote. I’d love to see it.

Now, don’t get me wrong. I’m a big fan of school spending. I’d love my city to truly embrace the idea of having excellent schools and the funds that go with it. And I’d be happy to pay for that excellence. I just want to see politicians stand up for it.

I’m not one for saying things in private that I won’t say in public. So…I’m really frustrated we have school board members running for council that recently voted for a massive increase in school spending and now seem to be reluctant? To talk about the taxes needed to meet their request.
I hear you. I’d love to see some leadership in our community on schools.

While folks in Arlington and Fairfax talk about raising taxes for schools, and Falls Church leads region in per pupil spending, I’m amazed nobody running for council is talking about creating/funding our schools to make them the best in the region.

Fascinating to watch so many in VA push Alexandria to raise its tax rate instead of do economic dev. Alexandria has one of the largest percentage of low income kids in NOVA, gets very limited state support for its schools, yet the answer from Richmond is raise your tax rate.
I’ve got birds fighting over the three birdhouses in my yard is how I know the housing crisis is hitting hard at all levels.
That is some messed up stuff. I mean, sassy mixed breeds have no business messing around.
I know, the city can pay for all the holes in its services and increase salaries by spending the money it wants to spend on the arena on other things…..oh, wait.
What does “best” mean? Fancy, casual, family-oriented? Pizza?
Other jurisdictions in NOVA are out there talking about how to have a truly excellent school system. Alexandria is so far floundering. Let’s go folks…get it together.
Looks like they start hitting around 2030, depending on construction time lines.
Arena money shot.
Lots to ponder with city budget. I’m worried about service quality in a few areas. I’m worried about sustainability. Lots of questions.
The budget impact of the Arena proposal would go a long way to fully testing the idea of whether truly investing in a diverse student body can pay off with graduation rates and life trajectory.
I think that could be true, but if ABC laws are meant to prevent public drunkenness, as he also said, his $5 jack and cokes are going to do a lot more damage than my $20 old fashioneds. ,
City goes hard showing how arena would impact/lower the taxes people pay.

My favorite testimony today was the restaurant owner who didn’t want changes and said “consumers don’t want premium cocktails, they want jack and coke. Nobody orders expensive stuff.” And all I could think was man, people must get really drunk at your restaurant.
Big hat tip to Elizabeth Bennet Parker and the bill’s patron, Bryce Reeves for presenting a bipartisan, unified front to modernize ABC laws.

OMG. Big showdown in Richmond today on effort to simplify restaurant alcohol rules. Big restaurants, who benefit from current regs, coming out in force to stop changes. Small guys (like me) fighting to keep up. Monopolistic restaurants…nuts.
Alexandria City Budget proposal drops today. Extra levels of civic geekiness about to commence!

The fact that we live at a time where one political party thinks deadnaming somebody is an act of political leadership makes me sick. We should be talking about how we improve people’s lives, not simply fighting to let people live as they want to. This shit doesn’t advance humanity. It destroys it.
Two great events by @@2432  and @@2422 today. If they are not elected to the next city council we are doing something really wrong.
You can also pair teachers up so they can co-teach and have more time for student individual interactions.

Re: schools. While teacher pay is important, I wonder where we would invest if we really said, let’s make the schools work. I think class size (mostly in elementary), social workers (so many kids need help that goes beyond learning), teacher aids, etc. are really important.

Been thinking about Alexandria budget a lot lately. Looking forward to seeing details this week. But what I’m stuck on is potential that we are significantly underfunding things to the detriment of results and quality and overall livability (schools, police, parks, etc). Worth considering?
Also, school board members who want to be on Council better explain pretty fast how they would fund their massive school budget request given low city revenues. I’m waiting…

Oh my, the debate over the city budget this year is going to be epic. We want to fund all the things but not raise taxes. Where is that magic waste, fraud and abuse section of the city budget? If only there was an economic development plan to address the lost commercial tax base.

I hear that. I think leaving that out of the Senate Dems budget was really odd…and unfortunate. I still think there is a chance everything gets figured out, but I also see a clear path to total chaos in Richmond.
Full legalization is a significant difference.
Pot can’t be sold in VA. You can grow your own, but there is no commercial market. No tax revenues. No regulations on quality.
The potential for a legalize pot in exchange for the sports arena deal in Richmond is fascinating.
This seems weird. I’m in.
Republicans literally want to stop people from having sex for fun. They hate sex. Despise it.
From what I have heard and seen, Speaker Don Scott in VA is doing a very good job. Nice to see it!

If the Arena framework in Richmond dies, which seems very likely right now without a Union deal, the Governor no longer has a reason to not just veto every Democratic bill he doesn’t like. It will be a bloodbath of killed bills.

My three questions for City Council candidates: 1) what does “tax base balance” mean to you and how do we get it? 2) what does “livability” mean to you and what do we need to do to accomplish it? 3) what does being a city of “opportunity” mean and how do we get there?

Spent my afternoon eating market to market, drinking a double IPA, sitting by an outside fire, and reading the Atlantic. It’s a little chilly out but I’ve got a big wool blanket and it’s a perfectly blue sky. Happy Presidents’ Day.

Big game of chicken going on in Richmond as Senate Dems oppose metro funding, the Arena, etc. with hopes they can leverage those things for pot legalization, school funding, and more. High stakes game, and if emotions get too out of control nobody will get anything.

The NOVA Dems that voted for a budget proposal that does not include new metro funding are playing a risky game. I know there is a lot of negotiating going on in Richmond right now, but leaning into hurting NOVA to make a point to the Gov seems pretty shortsighted.
My wife got me an amazing gift for my birthday. Really outstanding. And now I feel so much pressure for her birthday.
Yes, Carter is not innocent volunteer.

Agreed. Well, in the Alexandria proposal the city is an owner in the entertainment venue and my impression is Ethel have thought three a lot of the risk of the arena. More to learn, sure. Just waiting and seeing.
We should be free to live in a country where going to a parade or goingto school is not a risk to your life. This is a policy choice by elected officials.
Funny thing is that would likely actually be a bad deal.

The arena feels a lot like the waterfront to me. Opponents talked about high rises and a destruction of the city and an end to our tourism draw. None of that happened. Now the opponents fight for reservations at Ada’s and walks the waterfront walk like they always supported it.
Big VDay secret: La Fromagerie (one of best spots in Alexandria) does not take reservations and is basically empty tonight (VDY).
And reporters not asking this question are doing a disservice to the public.

Any politician in local or state government that does not have an answer for the lost economic value of office space is purposely lying to you. And saying, we just need to force people back to the office isn’t an answer - it’s a cop out.

I love to hate this
I love to hate that
You can tell by my sign
My dark heart reacts

Alexandria property assessments are out. Residential values up and commercial down. Any tax increases this year will be a double whammy on residential real estate, which is already seeing an increase. The Council is facing a significant budget gap that they need to close. Hard work ahead.
It is so hard to know given the potential motivations of the story tellers. But, also, authorities looked into it and did nothing. So…? What’s the point?
Oh my, that will surely keep Ukraine safe and stop our border issues.
Crazy thing is Allison is insanely disorganized. She also couldn’t hold on to staff because she was so cruel to them and so entitled. This piece gives you a glimpse as to why that may be.
Alexandria Times runs hit piece on Alexandria’s first black mayor without any point or hard data, just allegations from his political rival. A paper without ethics.

A lot of people who want big pay increases for teachers, well paid public safety, and more but are against economic development and higher taxes are going to have to face some very hard truths when the City budget comes out…or they will just put their heads in the sand and complain about bike lanes.

I notice that the yards with the anti stadium signs are the same yards that had anti housing and before that don’t bulldoze the park signs. I feel bad for people that expend so much energy hating things, never being curious, never trying to figure things out.
I expect a lot more changes. It has a lot of legislative sausage making to go through.

I’m seeing too many folks in Richmond who think Alexandria should either jack up property taxes for its high poverty public schools, public safety, public health, etc. or make dramatic cuts to those things instead because they can’t stand idea of giving the Governor a win.
So, this year’s presidential election is now about which side we want to be on when WW3 hits. Dictators or Democracy.

The intersection of tax increases, teacher pay, city staff pay in general, and economic development will be center stage during this year’s City Council elections in Alexandria. I hope the local media asks good questions, because candidates need to reconcile all this.

Absolutely insane that Republicans want to allow Fentanyl to keep coming into the country for another year or more instead of passing a border security bill now. They literally want kids to die from overdoses so they can “help” the Trump campaign.
If there is no tax base growth, higher pay for teachers and public safety and other key services, infrastructure, and other basic needs become very hard to fund.

With new economic data dropping showing almost no tax base growth in Alexandria, I’d like to see candidates with Council talking about what they would do to address this. Ignoring our economic structure and its many issues for residents is political malpractice.

I like the different background’s and focus areas from the new people running for City Council. I am eager to see more details about what they actually want to do. It is hard to really understand where they are coming from without more info.

As far as City Council races go, I may be a one issue voter this cycle. If you won’t commit to doing everything in your power to get Taylor Swift to perform in the DMV, especially with her new album dropping in April, you don’t deserve to serve.
There are so many people running for city council that seem to only stake their candidacy on a desire to be an elected official.
Trying to get my mind around fact that MAGA doesn’t want to close down the border but does want to close down Taylor swift.

But we shouldn’t discourage people who have day jobs either as that experience can 1) bring a lot to the table in policy development, 2) enable some people to serve for a while and then easily go back to private life, and, 3) attract people who are not just running for office to get a job.

I have mixed feelings about this. I do think Council should get paid significantly more as doing public service really stifles your ability to get ahead in your day job. Hard to promote somebody working a full time second job. People should be able to do it without a day job.
5) if you have no experience with economic development and land use issues, you better have a plan to get yourself informed. These are the bulk of what you will do. Same goes for the city budget.
4) voters will likely only remember one or two things about you. If you can’t identify that thing and are not prepared to repeat it over and over, you are not ready.
3) if you can’t explain what you want to do/why you are doing it, in 100 words or less, you are not ready to do it. Just saying you love the City or want to make it better is not specific enough.
2) if you are not ready to work 30 hour plus weeks reading and going to meetings, don’t do it. Ribbon cuttings are a small part of the job.
My general advice to people who want to run for City Council. 1) if you are not prepared to upset your friends, don’t do it. Few issues don’t divide your friends in some way.

I tend to follow the “be curious” approach to Alexandria civic life. I try not to judge too fast or get angry or assume my local officials are trying to destroy my life. I like to ask questions and assume people are usually trying to do their best. I think we’d be better off if that were the norm.
I definitely think we will see more candidates. I am waiting for the anti housing candidates. I’d be surprised if we didn’t get a few of those.
I have know John a very long time and like him. But I agree he is walking on thin ice with some of his votes. Definitely creating an opportunity for somebody to jump ahead of him in this race.
Say what you want about his love life, but that catch by TK 87 was amazing g.
Impressive kick off for @@2326 . Love the vision, energy, focus, and heart.
Kinda love that the anti arena folks think driving around blaring music is the way to win support. No arguments. No thoughts or ideas. Just a guttural hatred for change.
He is one of the best.
Have you all hired a bus to take you to kick off events as a group? Bonus points if it comes with bottle service.
No idea what this is.

Really excited, some may even say thrilled, or perhaps delighted to say I’m supporting the four incumbents for Council plus the tall one, Jesse. I’m going to keep my 6th spot a mystery until the very end.

This is a lot of performative BS from a group that walked away from a strong border deal so they could complain about not having a border deal. Biden should do a prime time talk from the border and call them out on it.

Went to my two spots tonight, Captain Gregory’s and Railbird Kitchen. Amazing crowd. Great atmosphere & vibes. Loved having a fantastic martini and burger at CG. Just all around wonderful. Place is really a place now after 9 years.
So “excited” that @@2422 has decided to try and bring the average height up on the City Council by many inches. Seriously though, we need serious and thoughtful people like him on Council.

Underlying this is the fact that current Virginia policy is designed to take resources from Alexandria without giving much back and then expecting the local residents in Alexandria to pay the majority of the cost of things — schools, sewer upgrades, mental health, community health, etc.

I think my favorite opposition group to the proposed Entertainment District in Alexandria are the Republican legislators who don’t support it because they don’t want Alexandria to do well or grow because the fear it will make the state too Democratic. Yes, people are saying this.
The people who think the world is only 6000 years old are going to be really upset about this.
I recently parked at the airport and thought the same thing. It is really out of control. Higher license fees for giant cars!

Alexandria VA needs an independent group of civic minded folks to analyze, review, talk about, and share views on major policy issues. Agenda Alexandria is biased towards folks who are knee jerk against things. I want a problem solvers group.
Please help us in our effort to put a nail in the quality life coffin of people who are not rich enough to own homes as we try to set legal precedent that could deny housing to generations of losers.
Yeah, I think the idea of balance is complicated, but doing nothing is crazy risky.

Translation: if you are not worried about our tax base balance between homes and businesses, and our resulting ability to pay for schools, safety, libraries, mental health, etc, then you are not doing civic activism right. Hint - we need more business taxes.

The group opposing the sports arena just put out a press release with notes bashing various members of the general assembly. I have to say, knee jerk opposition to things is really unimpressive. In a city as smart as Alexandria I’d hope opponents actually show some intelligence. Instead we get this.

Now that we [finally] have the long awaited and much needed pencil logo for Alexandria schools, can we talk about the fact that student achievement doesn’t seem to be the priority of our school system’s strategic plan?
Good chance he is against zfh. I think leading with you are for smart growth is likely code for housing not near him or people like him.
www.alxnow.com/2024/01/11/j...
The question is how much will he spend to try and make it so voters don’t know this.

When you spend almost 100k on political donations to, ahem, mostly Republicans and you have only voted in Republican primaries, saying you are not political and are now a Democrat running for mayor of Alexandria is going to take some serious explaining…welcome to politics Mr. Peterson
Thinking about all the folks in Richmond setting up for adult sleep away camp otherwise known as the General Assembly. Make good choices folks. Make us proud.

Insider info: Railbird Kitchen now has burgers and chicken sandwiches, plus a new wine and cocktail list (including our own espresso martini). And the duck fat tater tots are amazing…menu just dropped.
Went through three years of holiday cards today to collect the addresses. I am determined to do better at sending cards. But I probably won’t.
Back to the grad school grind today. Last January of grad school. Less than a year to go!
The transition from holiday hype to Winter doldrums can be hard on people’s mental health. Make sure to check in on friends.
Starting 2024 with a trip to the dentist. If this is an omen for the year, you all better strap in.
What does “hands we can trust” mean? Feels very coded.
Oh yeah! Yimby dance party!
Our morning present opening charcuterie board. Am I doing this right, or what? Merry Christmas all.
As an Alexandrian, I’m extremely proud of my Christmas Eve family outing to the pet store to get stocking gifts for all the pets!
Solid girl dinner presentation. Way to go you fighting against stereotypical gender paradigms.
Holiday old fashioned in hand, fire blazing, dog lounging besides me, a little holiday jazz playlist and here we go into the long weekend.
Just had a lovely meeting with Councilman McPike. I appreciate how thoughtful and solution oriented he is. We are lucky to have him on council.
I had a breakfast burrito from Rubia’s yesterday. It was fantastic.
What books?

One of my favorite parts of the history of Christmas is that Caroling started out as rowdy groups going door to door in search of alcohol - basically drunk trick or treating. People often broke windows and caused other similar problems.

While some people protest that “Merry Christmas” isn’t getting said enough, I want to start protesting that we go back to the initial Christmas celebration which was basically a multi-day drunken celebration. This didn’t start as a family holiday.
We read that last night as well!
What are folks burning for solstice night?
I just worry he isn’t interested in doing the actual work to make this a success. He always seems to be phoning in his policy work.
The Governor’s proposed budget does not give me confidence that the issues related to the sports center impacts will be easily solved. Is he a good partner?
That tree is so dense. A real clear political message about housing right there.
Oh, I didn’t see he announced. But yes, I expect more challengers with there already being two vacancies.
Yes. And while coming off Seminary off-ramp headed east.
Oh yeah, I’ve been tagged by that one. It is well designed to catch you before you have a chance to slow down.
Do we really just have one announced Dem (kinda a Dem) for Council? Waiting patiently for some progressive candidates who don’t buy into Republican talking points.

“‘Could they build it? Yes. Will they build it? No,’ [an economist] said, citing steep construction costs.”

We’re long from having an intensive national conversation about the need to build social housing — but not too long, I hope.
Last time I believe he endorsed more than 6 candidates.
Guy is listing an endorsement from the late Kerry Donley. Seems like his campaign web site is not ready for prime time.

If this sports complex happens at the current price point (which is a lot of money) I’d like to see a few things from the state: significant $ for committed affordable housing, big $ for metro/WMATA & DASH bus, $ to help build a new school in PYard, and likely a few more things.
Anybody read both Silver Nitrate and The Deep Sky? Which do I start first?
All the food groups represented here!

It is latke night at my house. Next to Christmas, this is the most popular night of the holiday season. The story of Hanukkah is a great story of cultural resilience and the preservation of faith. We should all be inspired by it.
On one hand we want a transparent and open process. On the other hand we are mad every transportation issue has not been solved before the public announcement. Sheesh…

Walking around the Torpedo factory. It is great to see the diversity (age, gender, ethnicity) of artists now. Really great stuff. I only wish the city did more to promote this place. ACVA rarely mentions it and both places are city funded.
I could give or take the sports, but the music and restaurants that we are going to get….will be amazing.
When I was on city council I called it the frosting phenomenon. We all love the cake but we bitch to no end about what frosting we should put on it.
Not for nothing, but in this economy keeping moral up is pretty key to staff retention.
I thought that piece was excellent. It was at done by at least one really quality writer. The tall guy is affable but, well…
The self hate Alexandria residents have for themselves and their community is really epic sometimes. This is a world class city. We should stop crapping on ourselves.
My best cocktails in Alexandria top 5. And I have been to most places. Captain Gregory’s, Kismet, Thompson’s Italian, Ada’s, Sister’s Thai. What are yours?
Cut my hair and shaved for first time in about 5 years (or more). Let’s start a rumor I’m running for office. But I won’t say which one.
If you are hiding things, it’s usually because you know they would hurt you.
Clearly these meetings need better snacks if they want to attract an appropriate level of drama.
Between the fruit and the Doritos I can’t tell if you are at a political event or a somewhat lame luncheon.
So far we are a good bit into this meeting and all I know is they have some decent snacks.

I like to think about Alexandria as a hopeful City. I hope that hope wins.
I have always believed Alexandria is a caring community where we look out for each other and avoid selfish or entitled ways of thinking. Exclusivity vs Hope. That is the choice.
This proposal is about ensuring people like me, that want to make Alexandria their home for the long-term, have a chance to do it. Exclusivity vs hope.
I live in a single family home. I’ve also lived in apartments, townhomes and row houses in Alexandria. Having housing choices at different price points allowed me to continue living in this City.

Proponents, many who live in apartments, say this plan gives them a little more hope that they may be able to buy a home in Alexandria, a goal that has become harder and harder, especially for people under the age of 40. Exclusivity vs hope and opportunity. That is the question.

Some opponents of change have said this proposal would destroy their quality of life, implying their happiness is somehow dependent on them living next door to expensive homes and the people that can afford them.

Proponents of the change have a vision of Alexandria as a city where young people have a chance to afford their first home and where retirees have the option to downsize while staying in the same neighborhood.
Ultimately, this is a values question. Opponents of any change believe single family only neighborhoods should generally be exclusive to the well off.

or should our zoning also allow for some duplexes and four-plexes that are more affordable for people entering the housing market for the first time or perhaps downsizing after a life in a larger home.
